As for her future plans, Fatmeh looks forward to opening a store, where she will work properly and offer her goods to a wider clientele which will return  higher profits to her.

loans.use: to purchase tools and supplies such as jars, containers, pots and some provisions

loans.name: Najah

texts.en:
Najah is a 56-year-old Lebanese married woman with two children. Najah supports her husband financially by working in the agricultural field, cultivating different types of vegetables. 

At this time, Najah is very eager to obtain a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l, as she wants to purchase agricultural supplies and fertilizer so that she can produce more, sell more, and gain more. 

Najah is a cheerful person who constantly stands by her husband to face the life obstacles and get over all the barriers.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies and fertilizer

loans.name: Pashke

texts.en:
Pashke wants to repair the animal food barn, and the amount she is requesting is 100,000 Albanian Lek.

Pashke is 47 and married; her children are 26 and 20 and they still live with her. It is almost traditional that children in Albania live with their parents until they get married. Some of them continue to live with parents even after they get married, but who will live with the parents is up to each family. However, one thing is for sure - only sons live with parents after getting married. 

Pashke does livestock for a living; she’s got four cows at the moment, and sells raw milk and baby calves to the local market of a little nearby town. In the agricultural land that she owns, she plants mainly Lucerne and fodder for the animals, and also some seasonal veggies for personal use and some beans and corn. 

Pashke’s husband is been paralyzed and receives a disability income.

loans.use: to repair a severely damaged animal food barn

loans.name: Nganga

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Nganga, 59 years old, and married with three children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa and has benefited from training on enterprise and financial management.

He is a mixed farmer who does both vegetables and dairy farming. He is taking a loan from Kiva  to buy quality dairy feed for his two cows, so that they can increase milk production to meet the growing milk demand. He believes this will help him support his children's education due to the increased income that he anticipates. 

Nganga is thankful to Kiva and their lenders, and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 47 years old. She is married, with four children who are between the ages of 3 and 15 years; three of them go to school. 

She has a shop, and has been working in a business for three years. 

After getting her loan, she would like to buy more sugar, cooking oil, soap and rice to sell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest, and to buy food for home consumption.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, cooking oil, soap and rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a refrigerator for a better upkeep of her food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy metal sheeting, wood, nails, cement, sand, bricks, etc. to build a roof for the porch and a bathroom inside the house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw material, supplies and maintain her machinery.

loans.name: Arshaluys

texts.en:
Arshaluys is a dance teacher. She opened a dancing studio a few years ago after graduating from the university. Her students attends dancing classes that Arshaluys provides with great pleasure. Arshaluys, together with some group of her students, participates at different weddings and other events as a dancing group. 

Arshaluys requested a loan, which she will use to purchase new tires and pay for transmission repair of the car. She also needs this loan to buy materials for preparation of new dresses for an upcoming performance. Her loan has been approved within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. This program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products.

loans.use: to purchase new tires and transmission repair and purchase materials for preparation of new dresses for coming performance

loans.name: Hiba

texts.en:
Hiba is a 45-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and four children who attend school. Her husband is a butcher and has worked for a long time in this occupation and he is the main income source of the family. 

Back to Hiba: she has worked in the agricultural field since 2013. She is quite new in this field but she was forced to get involved in this professional path as she had to supplement the family’s income. 

And today, Hiba wants to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l as she wants to buy fertilizer and seeds with the aim of augmenting her productivity, her sales, and, therefore, her revenue. 

Her main objective is to enhance her family’s way of living and provide them with the minimum life needs.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Gitau

texts.en:
Gitau is 51 years old, married, and has five children. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from trainings on enterprise development, savings mobilization, and financial management. His economic activity is dairy and vegetable farming.

Gitau requested a loan, which he will use to buy high quality cabbage seeds and dairy feeds. The loan will help increase crops and cows productivity resulting in an increased income. He plans to use the profits generated from this loan to meet his family’s basic needs such as food.

loans.use: to purchase dairy feeds and cabbage feeds.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
Francisco cuenta con dos hijos: el primero de 13 años de edad y es estudiante de la escuela de su comunidad, el segundo de 8 años de edad también estudiante, el es un hombre emprendedor que no le importa qué actividad realizar sino lo único que a el le importa es tener un ingreso económico para el beneficio de su familia. 

Su actividad productiva la cual le genera ganancia en su sistema económica es la compra y venta de ropa típica en su comunidad ya que es la única forma que el a podido encontrar para poder tener ingresos económicos para su familia, su segunda actividad es servir de jornalero en su comunidad y por medio de esa actividad el puede tener otro ingreso extra para poder mantener a su familia y darles una condición de vida apropiada  para sus hijos y que sean buenos profesionales en el campo laboral de la vida.

El es muy emprendedor en la vida y es por ello que el se decidió a la realización de un préstamo para la compra de mercadería de ropa típica, para tener a la disposición de la clientela más mercadería para su respectiva venta.

La aspiración más importante de el es la construcción de una mejor vivienda y darles un buen estudio a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Francisco has two children. The first is 13 years old and a student at the local school in his community, the second is 8 years old and also a student. He is an enterprising man to whom it doesn't matter what sector he works in, the only thing that is important to him is that he finds enough to have financial income for his family.

His work which generates income in his economic system is the buying and selling of traditional clothing in his community as it is the only way he has found to have revenues for his family. His second activity is working as day labor in his community Through this work he can have an extra income to help maintain his family and give them a standard of living appropriate for his children. He wants them to become professionals in their life's work.

He is very enterprising in his life and for this reason he has decided to take a loan to buy traditional clothing. He will than have more merchandise for sale ready for his clients. His biggest wish is to construct a better house and provide good education for his children.

loans.use: to buy traditional clothing.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Esther, who is twenty-two years old, married, and living with her husband. 

She is a mixed farmer who grows potatoes, cabbages, and peas and also does dairy farming. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 and has benefited from group management, savings mobilization, enterprise creation, and financial management training. From the training, she has been able to manage her business well and make good returns. 

She is borrowing a loan to further expand her business by buying dairy feed and manure. She hopes this will further boost the business and make better returns to help her in providing school fees for the children and also better clothing.

Esther is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the great support.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed and manure.

loans.name: Juan Pablo

texts.es:
Juan, es casado, vive con su familia integrada por su esposa y sus hijas, tiene la responsabilidad de generar los ingresos para subsistir con su familia; se dedica a cultivar granos básicos y a la crianza de ganado, estás actividades las aprendió de amistades, ya que le daban trabajo, los cultivos los realiza en tierras alquiladas, no tiene un horario establecido y ya cuenta con mucha experiencia.
El capital le será de utilidad para tener recursos para comprar abono para los cultivos de granos básicos, así tendrá todo lo necesario para trabajar y mantener estabilidad económica para cumplir con sus compromisos.
Sus sueños son mantenerse trabajando, tener mejores cosechas y dar a su familia un mejor entorno.
texts.en:
Juan is married and lives with his family which consists of his wife and children. He has the responsibility of generating revenues to sustain his family. He works growing basic grains and raising cattle. He learned these activities from friends as it provides them with work. He grows on rented land and he has no set timetable. He has lots of experience.

The capital will be used to have the resources to buy fertilizer for his basic grain crops. Then he will have all he needs to work and maintain his economic stability and meet his commitments. His dream is to continue working, have better harvests and provide his family with a better environment.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his basic grain crops.

loans.name: Aminu

texts.en:
Aminu is a maize farmer from Kurmi village in Kaduna state. 

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Aminu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Aminu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Aminu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure his children Iliya, Leatu, and Barnabas are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to meet urgent expenses like school fees and food and clothing, and to store his harvest so he can sell his maize later at higher prices

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
In the Florida sun, skin protection is a must! Luis created an all natural sun tan oil to provide quality skin care to sun-worshipers. His products are available online and Luis would like to expand his retail store presence. He says, “The greatest success I have had running my business was when I was able to sell a half dozen lotions to a store in Hollywood and they had them on their display. Two weeks later the lotions were sold out.”

Luis is originally from Ecuador and lived for time in NJ before settling in FL. His business supports himself, his children, and his mother in Ecuador. Luis became a US citizen in 2007.

While Luis has seen interest in his all natural sun tan oil, most retail outlets want more than just one product to sell. He has formulated a SPF 30 sunscreen for his product line and needs a loan to complete development of this product.

Check out his website: www.amazonictan.com

loans.use: to develop new product and grow retail sales

loans.name: Cándida

texts.es: Candida, se encuentra incorporada a organizaciones cuyas  venta las ofrece mediante guias especializadas de negocios o catalogo;idea que surgió a través de una amiga que la encaminó a este negocio; inició ofreciendo un kit de productos y ahorrando de los ingresos generados por la actividad que ella ejercía como empleada del servicio domestico.  Esta mujer que venció las adversidades de contar con tan escaso capital e incursionar en las ventas, lleva hoy en este negocio 10 años y con una clientela fidelizada.  Ella visita a sus clientes en el horario de 7 a.m. a 2 p.m., a los cuales les brinda facilidad de pago y productos de calidad. Candida quiere engrandecer su negocio,  por eso ella encuentra en el acceso al préstamo la posibilidad de tener una mayor cobertura para vender más y maximizar sus utilidades. Considera que con el aumento de sus ventas mejorará la situación financiera de su negocio pero necesita más artículos para la venta. Este es el septimo financiamiento que hace a la Gundación Mario Santo Domingo. En la actualidad está aplicando a un financimiento mediante el cual c, con los cuales logrará cubrir los pedidos que le hicieron sus clientes y espera que su negocio mejore en el incrmento de sus ventas. Esta emprendedora mujer tiene 59 años, es madre de tres hijos de 38, 37 y 30 años y una hija de 21 años. Ella desea que sus hijos creen su propia empresa para que tengan un futuro promisorio.
texts.en:
Candida is involved with organizations for whom she makes catalog sales.  The idea sprang from a friend who directed her to this business.  She started offering a kit of products and saving the earnings generated by the work she did as a domestic employee.

This woman, who overcame the adversities of having scarce capital and got involved in sales, has now been in this business for ten years and has loyal clientele.  She visits her customers from 7 a.m. until 2 p.m.  She provides them with easy payment and quality products.

Candida wants to expand her business.  That is why she is getting a loan.  It is the opportunity to have greater coverage, to sell more, and to maximize her profits.  She feels that with the increase in her sales her business’s financial situation will improve.  However, she needs more items to sell.

This is her seventh loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She is currently applying for a loan to manage to cover the orders her customers have made.  She hopes that her business will improve by selling more.

This entrepreneur is 59 years old.  She has three sons, ages 38, 37, and 30, and a 21 year old daughter.  She wishes for her children to create their own business so that they have a promising future.

loans.use: to buy toiletries, perfume, and clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase supplies, a used vehicle, and to start marketing campaign for his new company

loans.name: Juan Ovidio

texts.es:
Juan, opta por un nuevo préstamo para invertir en insumos agrícolas y pago de mano de obra para realizar los cultivos de granos básicos, de esa manera estará manteniendo su negocio funcionando.
Con la ayuda que los inversionistas Kiva le proporcionaron ha podido mantener la crianza de ganado y buenas cosechas de granos básicos, su familia se mantiene unida y muy saludable.
texts.en:
Juan has decided to get another loan to invest in agricultural inputs and to pay for labor to keep up his crops of basic grains.  That way he'll keep his business running.

With the help he received from Kiva lenders, he has been able to keep on raising cattle and having good harvests of basic grains.  His family his still close and very healthy.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs and to pay for labor to maintain his crops of basic grains

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en: Marie Louise is 42 years old. She is married with three children aged between 3 and 10 years; two of them go to school. She has a shop and has been running in a business for 10 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more salt, sugar, rice and soap for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy more salt, sugar, rice and soap for sale.

loans.name: Musa Barau

texts.en:
Musa Barau is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Musa Barau joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Gideon, Joy and Godiya.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Musa Barau would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Musa Barau can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Musa Barau spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and child school fees, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Dandila

texts.en:
Dandila is a maize farmer from Dutse village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Dandila would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Dandila can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Dandila, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Melody Women Group

texts.en:
In 2014, Melody Women Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to be trained on financial management and savings mobilization to help improve their livelihoods. Members are mostly involved in casual laboring, farming activities and businesses.

The person raising her hand in the photograph is Fridah, 30 years old. She is married and living with her husband and her two children. She operates a green grocery and has applied for a loan to add more stock of kale and vegetables to her grocery business. She hopes her business will thrive, and hence, help increase her income. This will uplift her living standards such as modern housing and better health care, and will also pay her children's school fees.

She is very happy with this loan and grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of kale and cabbages.

loans.name: Githima Gichiengo Shg Group

texts.en:
In 2012, a group called Githima Gichiengo SHG joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to be trained on financial management and savings mobilization.

The person on the left hand side is called Leah. She is forty five years old and lives with her three children. She farms vegetables such as tomatoes and carrots. She would like to expand her farming to earn more income. It’s for this reason that she is borrowing money to buy more planting seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

She hopes that a Kiva loan will help her increase her income, which will enable her to meet her daily expenses and support her children's education by paying school fees.

Leah is grateful to Kiva and all the lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase planting seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Mwireri Magina Self Help Group

texts.en:
In 2013 a group called Mwireri Magina Self Help Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) to be trained on savings mobilization and financial management.

Stephen, the person raising his hand in the photo, is 39 years old, married, blessed with four children and living with them.

He is borrowing from Kiva to buy iron sheets to roof his car washing business and also buy more washing detergents and other car wash requirements such as buckets, water tanks and pipes. He hopes this will improve on service delivery, hence raising his customer base. Stephen looks forward to an improved income that will enable him to meet family needs such as food.

He is grateful to Kiva and the entire lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy iron sheets to roof his car wash business, washing detergent, buckets, water tanks and pipes.

loans.name: Haydee Domilita

texts.es:
Haydee es una mujer felizmente casada y con 3 maravillosos hijos que vive en el Distrito de Pachacutec, Ica.
Desde que era joven viene trabajando como obrera de campo en su ciudad y con los ingresos percibidos ha podido sacar adelante a su familia y brindar una educación de calidad a sus hijos. También con mucho esfuerzo y ahorrando un poco pudo adquirir un pequeño terreno y está dedicándose al cultivo de uva porque quiere tener un negocio seguro para un mejor futuro de sus seres queridos.
Haydee está muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado podrá comprar los insumos necesarios para realizar el mantenimiento de sus cultivos de uva, de esta manera su producción mejorará y así poco a poco podrá terminar de construir toda su casa con material noble.
texts.en:
Haydee is happily married and has three wonderful children. She lives in the Pachacutec district of Ica.

Since she was young, Haydee has worked as farm labourer in her home city. With her income, she has been able to support her family and provide her children with a good education. With great effort and by saving a little, she has also been able to buy a small plot of land and works there growing grapes. Haydee wants to have a strong business so that her loved ones can have a better future.

Haydee is very grateful to Kiva lenders because the support they have provided will allow her to buy the necessary supplies for looking after her grape crops. This will allow Haydee to improve production and gradually finish building her home with stronger materials.

loans.use: to look after grape crops and have better production.

loans.name: Hamza

texts.en:
Hamza is a maize farmer from Dogon Fako village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Hamza would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Hamza can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

Hamza, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to meet expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Janulla

texts.en:
Janulla, a widowed 60-year-old, has been photographed with Lorenc, her 25-year-old and only child. Lorenc has been accepted in the master's program, and this is the reason why his mother is seeking your financial help: to pay for her son’s tuition fees.  

Lorenc has been working as a waiter in a well-known traditional restaurant in the city of Korca. The restaurant is built in an old house and serves all traditional food, including the delicious homemade grapa called ‘raki’ in Albanian, and this one in particular is boiled with cinnamon and honey. 

“My husband died when my son was very young, and I had to bring him up all on my own. It was difficult, yet worthwhile because he has turned out to be such a nice young man,” said Janulla, smiling.

loans.use: to pay for her son's tuition fees; he has been accepted into the master's program

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
As a married parent with two children, Dickson, who is 24 years old, works hard to support his family. He is both a dairy and vegetable farmer. Dickson is taking loan to purchase manure for his vegetable farming business, which he has been operating for the last two years. This will help improve on crop yield; hence, he'll be in a position to put up with the rising customer demand.  

He looks forward to increased profits and hopes that his business will go a long way in helping him support his family. Dickson is happy for Kiva and their lenders for the support.

loans.use: to buy manure for his vegetable farm.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret, 53 years old, lives with her husband, who supports her in raising the family. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA)  in 2013 and has benefited from the group's training in management, savings mobilization  and financial management.

Margaret is a mixed farmer involved in dairy farming and growing potatoes, cabbages and peas. She has requested this loan to buy manure to help boost her farm's output. She hopes her business will thrive and hence go a long way in supporting her children's education and meeting their basic needs, such as clothing.

Margaret is thankful for the great support of Kiva and its lenders.

loans.use: To buy manure.

loans.name: Florah

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Florah, 40 years old. She is married and blessed with four children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014 to benefit from training on enterprise development and financial management.

She farms vegetables such as cabbages and carrots and also does dairy farming. She is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer so as to boost her vegetable farming. This will help improve crop yield, leading to a bountiful harvest. She hopes to supply more products to the market, and hence, have an incremental boost in her income. This will help support her children's education by providing study materials and paying tuition fees.

Florah is happy for Kiva and their lenders for the financial aid.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizer.

loans.name: Mangorano Self Help Group

texts.en:
The person raising her and in the photo is Eunice, a member of the Mangorano Self Help Group in Limuru Kenya. She is 49 years old. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 to benefit from training on enterprise and financial management.

Eunice operates a small kiosk where she sells items like sugar, cooking oil and flour. She also runs a green grocery where she sells vegetables and fruits. She is borrowing money to add more stock in her kiosk. This will enable her to cope with customers' rising demand. She hopes this will increase her profits and in return uplift her living standard in terms of modern shelter and clothing.

She is very grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the continued support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of sugar, cooking oil and flour.

loans.name: Gitangu High Breeders Self Help Group

texts.en:
Titus, the person raising his hand in the photo, is 62 years old, married, and has two children. He is a member of the Gitangu High Breeders Self Help Group. The group members joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 to be trained on group and savings mobilization, enterprise development, and financial management. Titus is a vegetable farmer, planting potatoes, onions, and cabbages on his farm. 

Titus requested a loan, which he will use to buy planting seeds, thus increasing his vegetable harvest and income. This loan will enable him to continue supporting his family by providing basic needs such as food and clothing.

loans.use: to purchase planting seeds.

loans.name: Alba

texts.es: Alba, es una mujer  incorporada a empresas especializadas en la venta de productos por catalogo, dirigidos al aseo del hogar, también complementa esta actividad comercial con la venta de sandalias que le envía un familiar quien se encuentra fuera del país.  Alba tiene 55 años y su idea de negocio inició cuando su amiga le propuso  incorporarse a una comercializadora que ofrece productos mediante guias especializadas. Actualmente Alba tiene 14 años con este negocio y ha logrado cautivar una amplia clientela.  Ella realiza sus compras de contado y vende a sus clientes a crédito o contado según ellos lo requieran. Como desea tener más capital para poder hacer muchas mas inversiones y tener una mayor cobertura. La Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, le ha otorgado un crédito, el cual ha solicitado, para que pueda cumplir con su propósito de comprar articulos de aseo personal, mercancia para el hogra, sandalias etc. y tener una cartera de clientes más amplia.  Esta mujer desea continuar ayudando a su familia y a su sobrina, así como también sueña con ver prosperar su negocio, para cumplir su sueño de prosperidad.
texts.en: Alba, 55, operates a business selling home-cleaning supplies that she orders from catalogs and resells to her customers.  She also sells sandals sent to her by a relative who lives overseas.  Alba started the business after a friend proposed that she focus her efforts on products that aren't widely available in this neighborhood.  Alba has operated the business for 14 years and has many customers now.  She pays cash for the merchandise she buys and resells what she buys for cash or on credit, depending on the customer.  She is applying for a Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo loan to expand the range of products she sells.  She has borrowed from the bank before and will use the loan to buy merchandise--cleaning products, sandals, etc.--to stock the business.  The investment will allow her to grow the business and continue providing for her family.  She hopes and expects the business to prosper and provide her with a more secure future.

loans.use: to stock her business with merchandise--cleaning products and footwear--for resale.

loans.name: Bashir

texts.en: Bashir is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bashir would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bashir can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Bashir is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family and hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: To meet expenses like food, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Francine

texts.en:
Francine is 35 years old. She is married, with 4 children between 2 months and 12 years old, 3 of whom go to school. 

She has a shop and has been engaged in this business for 5 years. 

With the loan, she would like to buy more sugar, cooking oil, maize flour, and rice to sell. 

The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption and to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, cooking oil, maize flour, and rice to sell.

loans.name: Kuibanga Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Gladys, a member of Kuibanga Women Group. She is forty-eight years old, married, and a mother of three. Training on enterprise creation and management provided by Hand in Hand Eastern Africa has helped her realize her strength in business. She is engaged in a full-time business of dairy farming. She is requesting a Kiva loan to buy dairy feed for her cows. She hopes this will improve the milk production and she will thus be in a position to cater for her family needs.

Gladys is grateful to Kiva for the help and support.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed.

loans.name: Mukeu Unity Women Group

texts.en:
As a married parent with four children, Grace (who is standing on the right-hand side) is forty years old and a member of Mukeu Unity Women Group. She works hard to support her family. 

She is a dairy farmer, a business she has done for four years. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2014 to benefit from training in group management, savings mobilization, enterprise and financial management. She is taking a loan to purchase dairy feed and mineral supplements for her cows.  

She hopes that her business will thrive due to improved milk production leading to more profits. This will go a long way in helping support her family needs such as food and clothing. 

Grace is grateful to Kiva, and for the support of their lenders.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed and mineral supplements.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en: Claudine is 30 years old. She is married with one child who is 8 years old; she/he goes to school. Claudine has a shop and has been doing a  business for five years. With the loan, she would like to buy rice, sugar and salt for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and salt for sale.

loans.name: Nuhu

texts.en: Nuhu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Nuhu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Isti, Barnabas and Laazarus.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Nuhu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Nuhu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Nuhu  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children: Isti, Barnabas, and Laazarus, eventually hoping to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: To access a loan that meets expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Priscila

texts.en:
This is Priscila, thirty-five years old, married and a mother of one child. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from training on enterprise and financial management.

She does vegetable farming of indigenous kales, spinach and broccolis and also runs a saloon. She is borrowing money to boost her farming business by buying more planting seeds due to the high demand for vegetables in the area. She believes this will increase her profits which will help her support her family's basic needs and also her child’s education. 

She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: to buy planting seeds.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
As a married parent with two children, Hannah, who is fifty-four years old, works hard to support her family. 

She is a dairy farmer. She has been practicing dairy farming for the last two years. 

She is taking a loan to purchase animal feed and mineral supplements for her cows. She hopes the milk supply will improve, leading to higher profits. Hannah hopes that profits from her business will go a long way toward helping support her family and improve their overall living standards.

Hannah is happy with Kiva for the financial support.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed and mineral supplements.

loans.name: Munyaka Progressive Self Help Group

texts.en:
The person raising his hand in the photograph is Peter, fifty four years old, married and living with his wife and four children. He has benefited from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa training, which has equipped him with entrepreneurial and financial management skills.

He runs a charcoal-selling enterprise. He is taking a loan to add stock to his charcoal selling business. He believes that this will give him more returns and, hence, provide basic needs for his family, especially food, school fees and clothing for the children.

Peter is grateful to Kiva lenders for the support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Avatar Group

texts.es:
Avatar es el nombre de un grupo de préstamo que se encuentra cerca de un cerro. Desde lo más alto se logra apreciar toda la localidad y parte de sus colindancias, así como los sembradíos de caña, cabe mencionar que la vista desde esa altura es asombrosa.

Los integrantes del grupo son:

Xochitl-Venta De Comida 
Lazara- Venta De Pan Y Antojitos
Sonia-Venta De Ropa  
María De Lourdes-Venta De Manualidades Y Tortillas 
Leidy- Venta De Artesanía
Christian- Venta De Calzado Por Catalogo
Fausto-Venta De Toperware 
Angélica- Venta De Calzado Por Catalogo
Aurora- Venta De Longaniza Y Carne Enchilada

Y doña Celerina mejor conocida como la abuela Cele o Doña Cele, que tiene 80 años de edad y es madre de 10 hijos. Doña Cele es una mujer muy trabajadora, desde hace ya 40 años abrió una tiendita de abarrotes pues enviudó y sus hijos aún eran pequeños. Para ella, sus hijos han sido su principal inspiración además de la fe que tienen en la Virgen de Juquila y en San Judas Tadeo. Doña Celerina es muy devota y mandó construir una capilla justo al lado de la tienda. Para celebrar a sus santos en su día invita a todos los vecinos para orar y convivir por unos momentos. 

El éxito de su tienda de abarrotes se debe al buen trato y servicio al cliente que doña Cele les brinda a sus clientes y la poca competitividad que hay en el barrio. Con las ganancias obtenidas y un poco de las aportaciones de sus hijos ha ampliado la tienda y hecho algunas remodelaciones a su casa. También ha invertido en la compra de mercancía y carnes frías pues ha comenzado a ofrecer otro tipo de alimentos en la tienda y ha tenido buena respuesta. Por esta misma razón, quiere invertir en más lácteos y carnes frías, específicamente tres piezas de queso, jamón, salchichas, aceite y huevos.

*En la imagen: Doña Cele viste bata color azul.
texts.en:
Our community bank is called Avatar.  Our members live near a high hill from which we can look out over the town and the surrounding area.  From the highest point on the hill, we can see the sugar cane fields below, a view that everyone agrees is breathtaking.  

The members of our community bank are:

Xochitl-food sales 
Lazara- food sales
Sonia-clothing sales
María De Lourdes-crafts and food sales 
Leidy- crafts sales
Christian- footwear sales
Fausto-Tupperware sales
Angélica- footwear sales
Aurora-food sales

Doña Celerina, better known as Nana Cele or Doña Cele, is 80-years old and the mother of 10 children.  She started a corner grocery some 40 years ago after she was widowed and when her children were still young.  She says that her children were her inspiration and credits them and her faith in the Virgin of Juquila and St. Judas Tadeo for her success.  Doña Celerina is very devout and built a small chapel just outside her grocery.  She invites her neighbors to pray and congregate there on saint days.

Doña Celerina provides an excellent service to her customers and says that her store is one of only a handful in the neighborhood.  She has used her savings and money given to her by her children to expand the grocery.  She has also invested in merchandise that she hadn't previously sold and says that she is so encouraged by the demand for the new products that she wants to add others.  She will use this loan to buy dairy products, cold meats and other merchandise.

* In the photo, Doña Celerina is on the left, in the blue house dress.

loans.use: to stock the general store of one of its members.

loans.name: Llesh

texts.en: Previously Llesh bought goats and this brought improvements to the family financial condition. He is very appreciative to his lenders. "I had money coming in right away almost, and I was so happy, because I hadn't touched cash for very long time," Llesh said smiling in the interview. "With some savings, I made improvements to the house, yet, I'm not done with the things that I wanted. The winter is almost here and the repairs need to be done," continued Llesh.

loans.use: to make some repairs to the family home as there are four children who cannot live in the cold.

loans.name: Bahirwe

texts.fr: Le client BAHIRWE est marié à une femme sans emploie, père de 7 enfants et comptable au sein d'une institution sanitaire de la place. Après une sensibilisation intense de HEKIMA sur son produit éducation, il a sollicité un prêt pour lui faciliter le paiement des frais scolaires de ses enfants. Il remercie de tout cœur HEKIMA pour avoir songé à ce type de produit qui soulage les parents accablés par le paiement des frais scolaires.
texts.en: Hekima client Bahirwe is married to a wife who does not have a job. He is the father of seven children, and an accountant in a sanitary company where they live. After receiving training from Hekima on its education-related loans, he has requested a loan to facilitate the payment of school fees for his children. He thanks Hekima heartily for having set up this type of loan which makes payment of school fees possible for overwhelmed parents.

loans.use: to make payment of school fees for his children possible

loans.name: B. Bitrus

texts.en: B.Bitrus is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. B. Bitrus joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Aliyu, Mark and Luke.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, B.Bitrus would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to provide for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, B.Bitrus can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, B.Bitrus  spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to access a loan that meets expenses like food and child school fees, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa is a maize farmer from Tajiri village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Musa would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to provide for his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Musa can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Musa, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to access a loan that meets expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Lari Pioneer Vegetable Processors (C.b.o) Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Hannah, forty-five years old, married and living with her husband. She is a mother of three children and works tirelessly to support her family. She is a member of Lari Pioneer Vegetable Processors (C.b.o) group, which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from the training on enterprise creation and financial management. This has assisted in making her business flourish.

Hannah is a mixed farmer who raises potatoes, maize, cabbages and kales.  She is borrowing money to buy manure to boost her farming business. She hopes this will lead to improved crop yield hence income increment. This will enable her to support the children's education and provide them with basic needs such as food and clothing.

Hannah is happy for Kiva and their lenders for the great support.

loans.use: to buy manure.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Irene, thirty-one years old, married and blessed with five children.

She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH-EA) in 2012 to benefit from training on enterprise development, savings mobilization and financial management. She is a dairy, poultry, horticultural and vegetable farmer.

She is borrowing a loan to purchase poultry feeds. She believes this will further boost her supply and thus increase her profits. This will help support her children's education by allowing her to buy reading materials and also school uniforms.

Irene is happy for Kiva and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase poultry feeds.

loans.name: Sarayya

texts.en:
Sarayya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Sarayya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children, Caleb and Blessing. Before she became a member, Sarayya would have had to sell her maize at low prices soon after harvest due to her immediate cash needs to pay for such necessities as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sarayya can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Sarayya spoke of her  ambition to use the resulting additional income to provide food and clothing for her family, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: To meet expenses for food and clothing, thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest time

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Grace, thirty-nine years old and married. She has children both in primary and secondary school. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH-EA) in 2012 to benefit from training on financial management and enterprise creation. She is a dairy, poultry, horticultural and vegetable farmer. HiH-EA training has enabled her to improve on her financial and enterprise management as well as recordkeeping.

She is borrowing a loan to buy fertilizer and manure for her farming business.  She believes this will further boost the crop yield leading to improved income. This will enable her to provide for the family needs.

Grace is happy with Kiva and promises to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and manure.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
This is Esther. She joined Hand in hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to be trained on group formation, enterprise development and financial management. She is twenty-nine years old, married and blessed with two children.

She does vegetable farming of potatoes, onions and cabbages on her farm. She is borrowing a loan to boost her vegetable farming by buying fertilizer and manure. She hopes this will help improve on the crop yield. Esther looks forward to a bounty harvest leading to income increment. She plans to use the anticipated income in paying school fees for her children.

Esther is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy manure and fertilizer.

loans.name: Tia Bidii Young Mothers Group

texts.en:
Tia Bidii Young Mothers group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in the year 2014 to benefit from the training offered. The group has implemented skills acquired from HiH EA training such as group management, savings mobilization, enterprise development and financial management. Members have been able to manage their enterprises and also create new ones.

The person raising her hand in the photo is Alice, a widow who has two children whom she takes care of. Alice farms vegetables such as potatoes, carrots, and peas which she sells in the local market. She also keeps poultry and practices dairy farming.

She is borrowing a loan to expand her business by buying more vegetables to sell in the market. She believes that this will increase her profits so that she will be able to support her children's education and provide better clothing and basic needs.

Alice is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy more stock of vegetables such as carrots, peas and potatoes.

loans.name: Cathrine

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Cathrine, thirty-seven years old, married and a mother of four children. One child is in secondary school and two are in primary school.

She does both potato and dairy farming. She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and dairy feeds. Hand in Hand eastern Africa training has enabled her to improve on enterprise management, recordkeeping and also financial management.

She believes that both crops and animals will improve on their yield which will increase the supply volumes leading to more income. She will be in a position to meet her family's needs.

Cathrine highly appreciates Kiva and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and dairy feeds.

loans.name: Marvin Antonio

texts.es:
Marvin Antonio es un señor de 58 años de edad, originario del municipio de El Sauce donde ha vivido toda su vida, el cual queda ubicado al occidente de Nicaragua rodeado de montañas florecidas y ríos caudalosos donde predomina la agricultura y ganadería.
Don Marvin es casado y tiene a cargo a su madre y su esposa, él se dedica a laborar como maestro de primaria en una escuela de la comunidad Las lagunetas donde a diario viaja en su bicicleta para ahorrarse el pago del autobús, ya que generalmente los maestros en Nicaragua ganan tan poco que apenas alcanza para la canasta básica.
Don Marvin se siente muy agradecido con Kiva y Ceprodel por el apoyo que le han brindado a lo largo de estos cuatro años que tiene de trabajar con ellos, ya que gracias a estos financiamientos ha mejorado las condiciones de su vivienda y ha resuelto problemas de salud sobre todo.
En este momento tiene la necesidad de un crédito para realizarse unos exámenes médicos y comprar medicamentos para tratar su salud.
Espera que le sigan apoyando y que esta relación sea duradera.
texts.en:
Marvin Antonio is a 58 year old man, born in the city of El Sauce where he has lived all his life.  El Sauce is in the eastern part of Nicaragua, surrounded by mountains with flowers and powerful rivers, a place where agriculture and raising cattle are the main occupations.

Marvin is married and his mother and his wife depend on him for support.  He works as a primary school teacher at a school in the community of Las Lagunetas, where he travels daily by bicycle in order to save the cost of a bus.  Generally, the teachers in Nicaragua gain so little that they can barely afford the most basic everyday food needed. 

Marvin is very grateful to Kiva and Ceprodel for the help they have given him over the past four years that he has been involved with them, since thanks to the loans, he has improved his living conditions and, most important, resolved health issues.  At this time, he needs a loan in order to undergo some medical exams and buy medicines for his health.  He hopes for continued support and a lasting relationship.

loans.use: to undergo exams and buy medicines

loans.name: Isuf

texts.en:
Isuf does agriculture for a living; he plants and sells in large quantities to wholesale buyers: beans, onions, potatoes and apples. Kindly note, that his region is known for such produce.  

He’s been photographed inside the hut where he temporarily stores  his fresh produce; almost every house in the rural area has one or two huts. While his wife works in the family business, she works in agriculture about six months a year for others as well,  and she gets paid. 

Isuf is requesting this loan to rent some agricultural land from other villagers. Isuf’s village and the lands around are covered with apple plantations.

loans.use: to rent agricultural land from other villagers

loans.name: Bitrus Gogarma

texts.en:
Bitrus Gogarma is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Bitrus Gogarma joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Mallakai, Kathrine and Cicilia.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Bitrus Gogarma would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Bitrus Gogarma can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Bitrus Gogarma  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To access a loan that meets expenses like food and clothing, eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Ushirika Self Help Youth Group

texts.en:
Ushirika  Self Help Youth Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH-EA) in 2014 to be trained on financial management, enterprise development and savings mobilization to help members improve their livelihoods. The members in this group are mostly involved in agricultural businesses.

The person raising her hand in the photograph is Mercy, thirty-eight years old, married and blessed with two children. She sells clothes and also does vegetable farming. HiH-EA training has enabled her manage her  enterprise effectively and also keep proper records.

She is borrowing a loan to add more stock of clothes to her enterprise.  She believes this Kiva loan will further boost her sales volume hence bring in more income. This will enable her to cater for the family needs.

Mercy is happy with Kiva and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Mutirithia Women Group

texts.en:
In 2013, Mutirithia Women Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa for training on enterprise creation and financial management. This has helped the group members to manage their businesses well.
The person raising her hand in the photograph is Serah. She is thirty-nine years old, married, and has four children. She operates a small grocery, and sells charcoal as well. She has applied for a loan to add more stock to her charcoal selling business, so that she can meet her customers' demand. She hopes that this loan will lead to increased income, which will assist in paying her children's tuition fees and improve their general living standards, such as better health care and modern comfortable housing.
Serah is very happy with this loan and grateful to Kiva and their lenders for their help and support.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Le'atu

texts.en: Le’atu is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Le’atu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Ephraim, Shelemia and Sabina. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Le’atu had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to cater to her immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Le’atu can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Le’atu spoke of her  ambition to use the additional income to provide food and clothing for her family. Eventually she hopes to become one of the most profitable farmers in her community.

loans.use: To meet expenses like food and clothing; eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a school uniform and supplies for her son's schooling.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es: Edgar, Inició su negocio de almacén misceláneo en el año 2012, con el apoyo de su cónyuge y suegros; anteriormente él residía en otra ciudad de Colombia, pero llegó a Barranquilla en busca de nuevos y mejores horizontes.  Esta actividad que era totalmente nueva para él, le ha generado satisfactorios resultados. Desde su negocio ofrece ropa, calzado y otros artículos de este formato de negocio, así mismo aprovecha las épocas o festividades del  año para impulsar estos productos. Su local comercial abre todos los días a partir de las 8 a.m. y cierra a las 7:00 p.m. vendiendo sus productos de contado a los vecinos y transeúntes del sector por ello maneja una buena reciprocidad de la inversión.  Este negocio está ubicado en un barrio del municipio de soledad, en un sector muy concurrido por personas donde tiene clientes actuales y muchos pforman parte de su clientela potencial. Edgar   manifestó la intención de compra de artículos de navidad, ropa y calzado, pues debe aprovisionares en esta época siendo ésta donde se aumentan la venta de estos productos y se obtienen proporcionales ganancias.  La Fundación Mario Santo Domingo le está aplicando un crédito, pues  Edgar así lo solicitó, para capitalizar su negocio y pueda realizar sus comprar aprovechado la temporada. Su desafío es incrementar su capital de negocio, con ello poder tener su local y casa propia.
texts.en:
Edgar began his general store business in 20012, with the help of his wife and in-laws.  Before then, he lived in another city in Colombia, but he came to Barranqilla searching for new and better horizons.  He was completely new to this work; he has had good results.  

At his business he sells clothing, footwear and other items suitable to his kind of business.  In this way Edgar takes advantage of the season or the holidays of the year to move his products.  His commercial store is open every day at 8 AM and closes at 7PM.  He sells his products to neighbors and passersby for cash and thus manages a good return on his investment.  

This business is located in a neighbrohood of the city of Soledad.  It is an area much visited by people who are current customers; also many of these are part of his potential customer group.   Edgar wants to buy Christmas items, clothing and shoes, since he should stock these at this time of year since this is when the sale of those products increases and one earns bigger profits in proportion.   The Mario Santo Domingo Foundation is  providing a loan, since Edgar asked for it in this way, to provide capital for his business so he can make his purchases, taking advantage of the season.  Edgar's challenge is to increase his business capital; then he can have his own business location and home.

loans.use: to buy Christmas items, clothing and footwear

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
This is Tabitha, who joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 to benefit from its training in group, enterprise and financial management. A 26-year-old mother of three, she operates a small kiosk where she sells sugar, salt, flour and milk.

Tabitha has requested this loan to buy more stocks of sugar, salt, flour and milk to sell in response to rising demand. This will increase her profit levels and hence enable her to support her children's education by paying for school uniforms and school fees.

Tabitha is very grateful to Kiva and its lenders for their help and support.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of sugar, salt, flour and milk

loans.name: Kabuku Success Group

texts.en:
The person appearing on the left hand side of the photo is Hannah, 36, who is married and blessed with two children. She is a member of Kabuku Success group which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from enterprise development and financial management training.
She runs a small shop and also does vegetable farming of cabbage and kale. Her main goal is to expand her farming activities. It’s for this reason that she is borrowing a loan from Kiva to purchase certified seeds. She hopes this will boost her farming through improved crop yield, giving her more supply to sell at the market. She hopes this will increase her profits, enabling her continue supporting her children's education by paying school fee.
Hannah is very grateful to Kiva and its lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy planting seeds.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy merchandise of typical materials

loans.name: Kinungi Baraka Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Pauline, a member of Kinungi Baraka Women Group in Limuru, Kenya. She is thirty-eight years old, married and a mother of four children. She has benefited from Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) trainings, which have helped realize her strength in business. She is engaged in a full-time business of vegetable farming, dairy farming, and poultry farming.

She is taking a loan to boost her farming by buying hybrid planting seeds to enhance her farming business. She believes this will improve on crop yield and, thus, increase profits, which will in return help support her children's education by paying school fees and providing better clothing for them.

Pauline is grateful to Kiva and its lenders and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy planting seeds.

loans.name: Nuru Group

texts.fr: Madame MUNYERENKANA est une femme entrepreneur, courageuse et présidente de l'association de crédit NURU.Elle est agée de 46 ans, mariée à un maçon et mère de 13 enfants qui vont à l'école. Elle est vendeuse de friperie depuis 1989 suite au fonds reçu de son mari avant de rejoindre HEKIMA. C'est ainsi qu'elle sollicite un nouveau pret pour acheter 1 ballon de friperie afin d’agrandir son entreprise. Son objectif est de construire une maison et payer les frais scolaires de ses 13 enfants. Elle remercie vivement HEKIMA et ses partenaires pour le soutien.
texts.en: Mrs. Munyerenkana is a businesswoman. She is plucky and is the president of the Nuru credit association. She is 46 years old and married to a bricklayer. They have 13 children who all go to school. She has been selling secondhand clothing since 1989 when she received some money from her husband before joining Hekima. She now requests a new loan to buy one bundle of secondhand clothing in order to expand her business. Her goal is to build a house and pay school fees for her 13 children. Her sincere thanks go to Hekima and their partners for their support.

loans.use: to buy one bundle of secondhand clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing materials for resale

loans.name: Yahaya Jalo

texts.en:
Yahaya Jalo is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Yahaya Jalo joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Isah and Jalo.  

Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yahaya Jalo would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya Jalo can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. 

When asked, Yahaya Jalo spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: To meet expenses like food and clothing, and to store his harvest so he can sell his maize later at higher prices.

loans.name: San Antonio Group

texts.es:
El grupo San Antonio se ubica en una comunidad de enormes montañas donde también hay una cascada la cual alcanza su máximo nivel cuando llueve. La cortina de agua que se forma esconde una cueva que lleva hasta otra localidad. Las integrantes del grupo pueden además de apreciar los atributos de la naturaleza en cualquier momento, desempeñan una actividad económica para apoyar a sus familias: 

María Eugenia -Venta De Refrescos Y Dulces
Inés -Venta De Verduras
Lorena -Venta De Antojitos
Lorenzo - Venta De Refrescos
Margarita -Venta De Jafra
Adela -Venta De Ropa Para Dama
María - Venta De Mole
Saulo - Venta Del Plásticos
Ricarda -Venta De Comida
Reyna -Venta De Verduras
Teresa -Venta De Maíz  

Doña Georgina también forma parte del grupo, es mejor conocida como Gina y es madre soltera de una pequeña de 6 años de edad llamada Yeraldín. Gina ha dedicado 15 años de su vida a vender calzado y ropa interior por catálogo no solo en su comunidad sino también en las más cercanas. Todo comenzó gracias a su gusto por los zapatos y tomo más fuerza cuando se convirtió en madre, su hija significa todo para ella y por eso continua con su negocio. Gina entrega mercancía tres veces por mes, ella misma busca el calzado en la ciudad de Veracruz, a unas horas de donde ella vive. Con las ganancias obtenidas hasta ahora ha remodelado su hogar y satisface los gastos de su hija y los suyos. Gina necesita hacer una inversión para poder entregar los pedidos a sus clientes a tiempo: más de 15 pares de zapatos. “Siempre he pensado y soñado con poner una mini distribuidora de calzado y de esta manera hacer que más mujeres trabajadoras como yo sé auto-empleen”.

*En la imagen: Doña Gina viste de blusa morada.
texts.en:
The San Antonio community bank is nestled in the mountains near a waterfall that reaches its maximum force during the heavy rains here.   Local people have a strong appreciation for the natural beauty of this region and say that the curtain of water hides a cave that leads to another town.  

The members of the community bank are:
María Eugenia - food & drinks sales
Inés -vegetables sales
Lorena - food sales
Lorenzo - drinks sales
Margarita - Jafra sales
Adela - clothing sales 
María - food sales
Saulo - sales of plastic products
Ricarda - food sales
Reyna - vegetable sales
Teresa - maize sales 

Another member of the community bank, Doña Georgina, is better known as Gina.  She is a single mother with a 6-year old daughter named Yeraldín.  Gina makes a living reselling shoes and shoes.  She draws her customers from buyers in both her town and surrounding towns.  She started the business because she likes shoes, but it only took off when she had her daughter.  Gina's daughter is everything to her and her earnings from the business support them both.  Gina travels to Veracruz, some hours away, to buy merchandise three times a month.  She has earned enough from her business to remodel her house and provide for her daughter.  She is applying for a loan to pay for merchandise that includes footwear for which she already has orders.  "I want to work for myself and I have always planned to set up a small business distributing footwear", she says.

* In the photo, Doña Gina is wearing a purple blouse.

loans.use: to stock the footwear sales business of one of its members.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Joyce, who is thirty-seven years old and has three children. 

She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from training in enterprise and financial management.

She does dairy farming. Part of the milk produced is used for domestic purposes and the rest is put into commercial use. 

She has applied for a loan to purchase water pipes so that she can supply water for both domestic and animal use. This will ensure the animals get clean water, allowing her to save on costs incurred when treating diseases brought by contaminated water. She will also be able to maintain a stable milk supply and thus maintain consistent and increased incomes. 

Joyce will also be in a better position to support her children's education by paying school fees. 

She is very happy with Kiva and their lenders.

loans.use: To buy water pipes for supplying clean water to her animals.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos, trabajó durante muchos años en una empresa dedicada a la producción de calzado, él aprovecho su experiencia y en el año de 1998 decidió incursionar en su propio negocio de producción y comercialización en la línea de calzado para damas, niñas y zapatos colegiales.  Este hombre emprendedor de 46 años,  es proveedor de almacenes de calzado en Barranquilla, pero también en otras ciudades del norte de país.  Carlos elabora calzado de calidad y con excelentes acabados, maneja buenos precios; es por ello que cuenta con un grupo significativo de clientes.  En ocasiones su capacidad de producción le es insuficiente y no le permite cumplir con los pedidos por múltiples variables, es por ello que lucha por adaptar la capacidad de producción a las demandas del mercado.  Esta es la razón por la cual se ha acercado a la fundación Mario Santo Domingo para aplicar a un crédito, para la compra de insumos de producción como suelas, herrajes, pegantes, capellada, forros con lo que se espera cubrir los requerimientos de pedidos y recibir ganancias promisorias por la temporada decembrina.  Carlos desea a futuro ser reconocido en la ciudad de Barranquilla y lograr incorporarse como proveedor de otros almacenes de calzado. Sus compras de materiales las realiza de contado en las peleterías de Barranquilla.
texts.en: Carlos worked for many years at a shoemaking business. He took advantage of his experience and in 1998 decided to tackle his own business making and selling shoes for women and girls and school shoes. This enterprising 46-year-old man is a supplier to shoe stores in Barranquilla, but also in other cities in the northern part of the country. Carlos makes quality shoes with excellent finishes and his prices are good. That is why he has a significant group of customers. On occasion his production capacity is insufficient and does not allow him to fulfill orders for multiple reasons. That is why he is fighting to adapt his production capacity to the demands of the market. This is the reason for which he has approached Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to apply for a loan to buy production supplies such as soles, metal hardware, glue, vamps, and linings, with which he hopes to be able to cover the requirements for orders and receive promising earnings for the December season. In the future, Carlos wants to be recognized in the city of Barranquilla and succeed in establishing himself as a supplier to other shoe stores. He purchases his materials in cash at the furriers in Barranquilla.

loans.use: to buy production supplies such as soles, metal hardware, glue, vamps, and linings

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy condiments.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy equipment for his computer- and copier-services business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural produce for warehousing and later sale to wholesalers

loans.name: José

texts.es: José, fue empleado en una tienda donde aprendió todo el manejo de éste formato de negocio, experiencia que lo encaminó a iniciar su propia tienda de víveres, ranchos, licores, bebidas etc. en el año 2009 y cuyo capital de entonces, fue la liquidación que le pagaron en aquel trabajo. Él labora de la mano de su cónyuge y  atienden el negocio desde las 6 a.m. hasta las 9:30 p.m., con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio. La tienda tiene un variado surtido en productos de consumo masivo, y un excelente flujo de caja diario; sus ventas las hace de contado y a crédito, sus clientes son sus vecinos y transeúntes del lugar. Las compras las realiza de contado a sus proveedores. Su  negocio funciona en un local, ubicado en un barrio del municipio del Atlántico donde habita; Como  desea ampliar su negocio y mejorar su stock de productos, está aplicando a un financiamiento en Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, es su primer credikiva,  el cual utilizará para proveer de productos a su negocio como bebidas, refrescos, víveres, cárnicos, lácteos etc. Sus metas familiares están encaminadas a comprar su casa propia puesto que ellos  desean brindarle una mejor  calidad de vida y un futuro promisorio a su hijo de 8 años, para potenciar su éxito futuro.
texts.en:
Jose used to be employed in a store where he learned how to manage this type of business. This experience  led him to start his own grocery store in 2009, selling snacks, liquors, drinks, etc. The capital since then has come from his separation pay from that job.

Jose and his wife work together, tending to the store from 6:00 am until 9:30 pm with great effort and sacrifice. Their store offers a varied selection of products of mass consumption with excellent daily sales for cash and credit. The customers are neighbors and people passing through the area. Jose pays the wholesalers in cash. His store is in a public market, located in a municipal barrio of Atlantico where they live.

Since he wants to expand his business and improve its stock of products, Jose is requesting financing through the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. This is his first Kiva loan, which he will utilize to stock up on products for his business, such as drinks, soft drinks, groceries, meat, dairy products, etc. 

His family goals are aimed at purchasing a proper house, since he wishes to offer a better quality of life and a promising future for their eight-year-old son, to aid in his future success.

loans.use: restock his store with products such as drinks, soft drinks, groceries, meat, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Memory

texts.en:
Memory is running a growing poultry business. She started with 50 birds and upon receiving her first loan she increased to 100 birds and later discovered that she could make more from producing more. She has a current capacity of 100 birds every two weeks. 

She bought stationery for needy primary school students and she collaborated with other Cama members to donate football and handball kits. Her business is very profitable, as evidenced by the record books showing an average of $300 profit per every batch of 100 broilers. 

With the new loan, Memory would like to continue increasing her chicken production.

loans.use: to purchase more broiler chicks and chick feed to increase production.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
When Judith received her first loan, she used it to restock her shop and add more shelves. Her sales have improved ever since. She has used the profits to provide for her family. 

She intends to convert into a general dealership, and purchase more stock.

loans.use: to turn her shop into a general dealership and purchase more stock

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
The Kiva loan has benefitted Winnie significantly. Her profits increased as a result of the increase of stock, which has resulted in high sales. She has thus become self-reliant, and able to financially provide for her family. She also managed to buy building materials for her mother’s house, and pay for her examination fees for the Ordinary Level subjects that she would like to take in November. Of more importance, she managed to make her loan repayments timely throughout the loan term.

However, she is also facing challenges in her business, but they are not substantial. Some of the debtors do not make their payments on a timely basis, and this affects the flow of cash in her business. 

Despite this challenge, she has plans for the future which include continuing with her business and take it to a larger scale if she is to get a second loan.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries in order to increase sales.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase livestock vaccines

loans.name: Bvumai

texts.en:
Bvumai was one of the early beneficiaries of Kiva's field partner Camfed's programs to provide financial assistance to ensure that young girls go to school. She started her business selling clothing in 2011. Thanks to her first Kiva loan, she has been able to expand to a second booth at a local flea market and significantly increase her profits by buying her stock in bulk. The quality of life for her and her children has improved thanks to her loan. "My children are living a better life," she shared.

In addition to caring for her own two children, she is supporting two other children who were left orphaned by the death of one of Bvumai's sisters. The biggest challenge to her business has been the rough - sometimes impassable - roads between her remote village of Mola and the nearest sizable town of Karoi. But this is a challenge she and others in Mola face every day, and find ways to adapt to get what they need.

Because of the success of her business, she plans to send her children to better schools. Bvumai is now a role model in her community, and looked up to by other young girls who are striving to follow her example. She hopes to receive another Kiva loan to expand to a larger shop, where she can increase and diversity her inventory

loans.use: To expand her shop and purchase more stock

loans.name: Tendai

texts.en:
After receiving her first loan from Kiva, Tendai expanded her business and bought more stock. Now, she does not suffer much from local competition because she has a variety of goods at her table. 

From the profit she gets monthly, she is now able to buy food for her whole family and pay school fees for her children. The loan elevated her business, which was about to shut down due to lack of money. 

Now, Tendai has moved her business to a good location and she wants to grow her business, so that she can build or upgrade her home. 

Tendai sends regards to her funders. She is so grateful to have received a loan and she looks forward to receiving another loan to increase her clothing inventory.

loans.use: to purchase more towels, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, track suits, and T-shirts to increase her clothing inventory.

loans.name: Marble

texts.en: Marble has a poultry business. She intends to extend her fowl run so that it can accommodate between 400-500 birds at a time. She has completed the construction of her three-room house using the profits from her business. Marble has been able to pay back her previous loan. She is happy and also wishes that the Kiva loan program expands and helps more people.She wishes to get a second loan so that she can boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more broiler chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella’s business is doing well. Before receiving her first loan, she used to sell her groceries at home but now has built a shop. With the proceeds from her grocery business, she has managed to meet all her family needs. Stella is also paying fees and providing for her brother-in-law's education. He is taking level three courses at a local school. Stella has also created employment for her husband since he is actively involved in the business and he is the one who usually goes and gets the orders. Stella has ventured into market gardening, selling tomatoes and green maize. She has overcome competition by doing promotions and by having discounted prices on some items to encourage customers to buy more. Her major challenge has been her failure to meet customer demand due to lack of capital. Her aspiration is to purchase more farm produce and grow in business and be recognized in the community.

loans.use: To purchase more farm produce for her grocery business.

loans.name: Fluturije

texts.en:
This is Fluturije (which means butterfly in English) and Shpetim, her husband, who are seeking your help and compassion. They need money because their daughter has been scheduled for a kidney surgery. 

“We are very worried for our daughter. She’s been suffering from kidneys now for a very long time and had had other surgeries. Let’s see, we try to remain positive and put on a smiley face at times," said both of them almost unanimously. 

They both are retirees and receive their retirement pension. In addition to this little income, they make some monthly income from the rental of their house to a local bank. 

Their family lives in the city of Korce, in the southeastern part of the country. They are parents of three.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter's kidney surgery

loans.name: Sekai

texts.en: After receiving her first loan from Kiva, Sekai managed to expand her poultry business. Now she does not suffer from any competition because she has a variety of products. She is now able to buy basic commodities for home consumption. She has managed to buy a cow and clothes for the whole family. Apart from this, she also managed to pay the hospital bills of her mother-in-law and pay exam fees for herself. Sekai said she really appreciates the loan that she got from Kiva because it has changed her standards of living. She is now proud that she can afford to buy basic food for the whole family. She hopes to get a bigger loan for more broiler chicks and feed so that she can increase her production.

loans.use: to buy more broiler chicks and feed to increase production.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Spiwe

texts.en: From the time Spiwe received her previous loan, her life was transformed.
