Before receiving the loan, her monthly income was below (USD) $200 and now she is earning more than (USD) $400 per month from her grocery business. She can now buy orders in bulk. She also bought a 2.5 ton truck from the profits. Spiwe has been able to support her family and give other family members start-up capital so that they will not be fully dependent on her. She also used profits to pay for lessons since she is supplementing her Ordinary Levels for a general education certificate. This loan has made her a role model. Her aspiration is to pass her Ordinary Levels and make people in her community realize that women can achieve. She hopes to further boost her business by increasing her grocery stock with a new loan.

loans.use: To increase her grocery stock

loans.name: Gicel

texts.es: Gicel,trabajó por muchos años como vendedora en distintos almacenes, experiencia que le genero la seguridad y predisposición al éxito para emprender su propio negocio. En el año 2002,  invirtió unos ahorros que tenia en artículos para la venta, ropa, calzado y colonias,  que ofreció a sus amigos y familiares y estos le compraron. A partir de ese momento empezó a ver los frutos de su trabajo y a ayudar con los gastos del hogar.  Gicel tiene 33 años, es madre de tres hijos, un niño de 14 y 2 niñas de 8 y  12 años. Gisel desea tener su casa propia, para brindar un mejor bienestar a su familia, es por ello que con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación labora diariamente 10 horas. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financimeinto que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo lmediante el cual comprará ropa, calzado y colonias. Ella realiza sus compras a sus proveedores de contado y brinda facilidad de pago a sus clientes. Este negocio se ha mantenido gracias a la buena rotación de la cartera y su  excelente servicio.
texts.en:
Gicel worked for many years as a saleswoman at various stores, experience that gave her the confidence and predisposition to start her own business. 

In 2002, she invested some of her savings in items for sale: clothing, footwear and colognes She offered these to friends and family and they bought them. From that moment, she began to see the fruits of her labours and was able to help with the household expenses. 

Gicel is 33 and the mother of three children, a boy of 14 and two girls aged 8 and 12. Gicel wants to have her own home, to provide a better quality of life for her children, which is why she works for 10 hours a day with a lot of effort and dedication. 

She is now applying for a Kiva loan, the first application which she has made to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation. Through the loan, she will buy clothes, shoes and colognes. She makes purchases from her suppliers in cash and provides her customers with easy payment options. This business has been maintained thanks to the good turnover of different products available and her excellent service.

loans.use: buy clothes, shoes and colognes

loans.name: Yvonne

texts.en: After receiving her first loan from Kiva, Yvonne managed to expand her business and purchase more clothing stock. Now competition is a thing of the past because she sells a variety of clothing lines which makes her business more desirable to customers. She is now able to afford basic commodities for home consumption as well as clothing. She also managed to improve the look of her home by buying paint and painting their home inside and out. She hopes to get another loan so that she can continue to grow her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more cooking supplies for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and  t-shirts to increase her supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more bags, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits, and t-shirts to increase her clothing supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes, bags and towels.

loans.name: Mutirithia Women Group

texts.en:
In 2013, Mutirithia Women Group joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to be trained on enterprise development.

The person raising her hand in the photograph is Mary, a member of this group. She is 63 years old, a single mother and has four children. She operates a small shop where she sells items including cooking ingredients and other household items. She has applied for a loan to add more stock of sugar, salt, cooking oil and flour to her shop so that she can increase her sales and meet her customers' rising demand. She hopes that this loan will help increase her income, which will in return help improve her living standards, such as better housing and health care.

She is very happy with this loan and grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: To pay for more stock of flour, cooking oil, sugar and salt.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a large bale of clothing and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Fiona

texts.en: Fiona’s business is very successful. She has been able to buy kitchen chairs, two goats and pay school fees for her two children. She also bought clothes, food and blankets for her parents and siblings. She renovated her house and was able to further her education. Her living standards changed in terms of reputation and financial independence. Now she is able to buy a variety of products in bulk for her business, so she bought about 200 shirts, 300 blouses, 200 trousers, 100 pairs of shoes and 300 skirts. She also ventured into poultry production and expanded her current business. She has many customers. Her business aspiration is to build a big shop and employ more people. Her hope is to get a bigger loan so that she can continue to expand.

loans.use: To purchase more towels, shoes, jeans, shirts, skirts, tracksuits and t-shirts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more broiler chicks and chicken feed to increase production.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Joyce. She is 51 years old, married and a mother of three children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa and benefited from business development training that helped her realize her strengths. She engages herself in the full-time business of dairy and poultry farming. She supplies her farm produce (eggs and milk) to the nearby market.

Joyce is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy dairy and chicken feeds. She is very happy for Kiva's financing, as she will be able to increase her production, hence earning more profit in the farming business. Joyce promises to pay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy chicken and dairy feeds

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
The person in the photo is Susan. She is 54 years old, married and blessed with six children. She is a charcoal seller in a small market in Limuru, Kenya and also practices dairy farming. 

She plans to expand her enterprise, though she is constrained financially. For this reason, she wishes borrow money to add more stock to her charcoal sales business to help meet her customer demand. She hopes that this loan will help increase her income, which will help her to improve her living standards, such as being able to access better health care.

Susan is happy with this loan and grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the help and support.

loans.use: To add more stock of charcoal.

loans.name: La Guadalupe Group

texts.es:
El grupo La Guadalupe se ubica en una zona cañera. En cuestión de días comenzará el periodo de zafra (corte de caña) para procesarla en alguno de los ingenios (fábrica azucarera) que también se encuentran en los alrededores: uno de ellos a 20 minutos, el otro a 30 minutos y algunos a una o dos horas. Afortunadamente las fábricas son una fuente de empleo para los habitantes mientras que muchos otros trabajan en campo sembrando, cuidando y cortando la caña para que sea procesada.

Los integrantes del grupo son:

Leticia- Venta De Pollo
Maricela- Venta De Ropa
Mercedes-Venta De Calzado Por Catalogo
Irma-  Venta De Comida
Luis Felipe-Venta De Calzado Por Catalogo

Diana también es integrante, es una joven de 19 años de edad y madre de una pequeña de 6 meses. Desde hace un año se ha dedicado a vender ropa, fue sus suegra quien la incitó a iniciar la actividad pues ella tiene un local. Al principio Diana le ayudaba, pero más tarde decidió adecuar un espacio en su casa para tener su propio negocio. Hace 6 meses, Diana decidió ampliar la variedad de productos y comenzó a vender calzado por catálogo. Con las ganancias obtenidas y el sueldo que percibe su esposo han ahorrado para comenzar a construir el patrimonio de su familia. Diana quiere invertir en blusas, pantalones, faldas y algunos pedidos de zapatos que sus clientes le han solicitado.

El grupo La Guadalupe agradece a VisionFund por la gran oportunidad de crecer con sus negocios y su familia. 

*En la imagen: Diana viste de blusa color rojo.
texts.en:
La Guadalupe Group is located in a sugar-cane region.  In a matter of days the sugar-harvest season begins for processing the cane in some of the "ingenios" (sugar mills), which are also located in the area: one of them about 20 minutes away, another about 30 minutes, and some an hour or two.  Fortunately the factories are a source of employment for the residents; others work in the fields growing, maintaining, and cutting sugar cane to be processed.

The group members are Leticia, chicken sales; Maricela, clothing sales; Mercedes, catalogue sales of footwear; Irma, food sales; and Luis Felipe, catalogue sales of footwear.

Diana, 19, is also a member.  She's the mother of a six-month-old baby girl.  She has worked selling clothing for a year.  Her mother-in-law got her started in the job because she has a retail space.  Diana helped her in the beginning, but later she decided to set up a space in her house to have her own business.  Six months ago Diana decided to expand her products and started making catalogue sales of footwear.  With her profits and the salary her husband earns, they've saved money to start building the family home.

Diana wants to invest in blouses, pants, skirts, and some footwear her customers have ordered.

La Guadalupe Group is grateful to VisionFund for the wonderful opportunity to grow with their businesses and their families.

Diana's wearing a red blouse in the photograph.

loans.use: to buy blouses, pants, skirts, and some footwear requests from her customers

loans.name: Women / Men Of Hope Group

texts.en:
As a married parent with two children, Jane (who is raising her hand in the photograph) is 30 years old and a member of Women/Men of Hope Group. She works hard to support her family. She buys vegetables from local farmers and supplies them to the local market. 

Jane is taking a loan to add more stock of carrots to her vegetable business, which she has been operating for the last two years. She has gained consistent customers in her enterprise, hence she needs to maintain a stable supply of her products. She hopes that her business will flourish, thereby improving her income. This will go a long way in helping to support her family's needs, such as food and clothing. 
 
Jane is happy with Kiva and its lenders for the support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of carrots to sell

loans.name: Yamiles

texts.es: Yamiles, inició su negocio de miscelánea en el año 2013, su madre  fue quien logro convencerla para iniciar este negocio, puesto que ella es tambien comerciante. Yamiles tiene 25 años de edad y su negocio funciona desde su casa, que esta ubicada un barrio del municipio de Barranquilla. Su miscelánea tiene un inventario diversificado, ofrece colonias, cremas, cosméticos, productos capilares y demás artículos que se venden en este formato de negocio.  El horario de atención en su negocio es de 8 a.m. a 7 p.m.  y vende diariamente, por lo que tiene un buen flujo de caja, sin embargo su capital le es insuficiente para atender la demanda, es por ello que está aplicando a un crfedikiva en la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para invertir en la compra de artículos como perfumes y colonias, cosméticos y demás productos que ella comercializa. Yamiles realiza sus compras de contado en las distribuidoras y mayoristas de Barranquilla.  Este negocio es muy concurrido por sus clientes que son vecinos y amigos, lo que garantiza la pronta recuperación de la inversión. Para mejorar su estilo de vida desea a futuro independizar su negocio de la vivienda familiar, y ahorrar para comprar su propio apartamento, es por ello que su gran desafío es aumentar sus ventas para generar recursos y poder ahorrar para sus sueños.
texts.en:
Yamiles started her corner shop business in 2013. Her mother persuaded her to start this business, since she is also a shopkeeper. 

Yamiles is 25 years old and runs her business from home, which is in a district of the municipality of Barranquilla. Her shop has a diverse stock: colognes, creams, cosmetics, hair products and other items. The opening hours of her business are 8 am to 7 pm daily, so she has a good cash flow.

However her capital is insufficient to meet the demand, which is why she is applying to the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation for a Kiva loan to buy items such as perfumes and colognes, cosmetics and other products which she sells. 

Yamiles buys from distributors and wholesalers in Barranquilla, paying cash. This business is very popular with her customers who are neighbours and friends, ensuring a prompt return on investment. 

To improve her lifestyle, in the future she wants to separate her business from the family home and save to buy her own apartment. This is why her great challenge is to increase her sales to generate resources and be able to save for her dreams.

loans.use: to buy items such as perfumes and colognes, cosmetics and other products whch she sells

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goods for her grocery store.

loans.name: Tinei

texts.en:
Tinei used her first loan to increase her merchandise at her stall in the flea market. She later made enough profit to rent space in a shop. She is selling and making profit of almost USD 200 per month. She sometimes receives orders from her customers that require her to do door-to-door delivery of the clothes. 

The profits of her business have been channeled towards the development of her home. She has been able to meet the medical bills for her daughter and has paid fees for her young sister who is in primary school. 

Tinei has been giving back to her community through buying food and clothes for vulnerable and terminally ill students at the secondary school, where she volunteers. 

A bigger loan will enable her to expand her business.

loans.use: to purshase more wares for her clothing shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more relish, frozen soda drinks, and cereals to sell.

loans.name: Yinani

texts.en:
The loan was very beneficial to Yinani’s business. Since she received the loan, her business improved both in sales and in profit levels. Using the additional profits from her business, she paid her examination fees to complete her secondary education. She can now pay her rental, water and electricity bills of $100.00 per month. She is also paying for her house that is being built in Binga. Above all, she managed to repay her loan in full in time.

She is planning to continue with her business and so much looks forward to receiving a second loan to boost her business to greater levels. She has been saving funds in order to build her own shop. Her wish is to get a second loan.

loans.use: to purchase a wider variety of products.

loans.name: Laizar

texts.en:
Laizar’s business is still running very well since she received her USD 500 loan from Kiva in April 2014. She has been able to buy a few clothes and a few groceries, but the loan has improved her business to a greater extent.

She can now assist in meeting the financial needs of her family and developing herself. She managed to pay the examination registration for the ordinary level subjects that she would like to take in November. 

If she gets a second loan, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy wash soap, sugar, and matches to sell.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
After receiving her first loan, Rosemary built a very big fowl run at her home that she is using for rearing chicks, and bought more feed and chicks. 

Using the profit she gets from selling broilers and manure, she managed to buy four goats, electric gadgets such as a solar inverter, battery, and upgrade for her bedroom suite. She also managed to pay school fees her children and pay medical bills for her son who was involved in an accident on his way from school. She managed to change her standard of living by purchasing clothing and food for the whole family. 

Rosemary really appreciates the loan that she got from Kiva because it has changed her life. She started another business of buying and selling clothes. She is no longer financially crippled like before. Rosemary now can afford to buy basic commodities for the whole family. 

She looks forward to receiving another loan so that she can increase her production capacity.

loans.use: to purchase more broiler chicks and chick feed to increase production.

loans.name: Maa Tarini Group

texts.en:
Maa Tarini Self-Help Group (SHG) was formed in July 2014. The group consists of eleven rural poor women members who belong to Below Poverty Line. This group is located in a rural village named Kutrabeda of Nuapada district of Odisha, India. 

Rasmita is one of the members of this group. The lady standing fourth from the right with a raised hand is Rasmita. She is a very active and young lady of 21 years of age. She lives with her husband and one child of 1.5 years. Rasmita is very much keen to contribute some income to her family by doing a business of her own.

The main income source for Rasmita is procurement of paddy during the harvesting season at a cheap rate and selling it when the rate is high. Her husband moves to weekly markets and procures paddy from the farmers. He does this work for three months (December through February), which is mainly the harvesting season for paddy. Apart from this, Rasmita has also a general grocery store in her house, which is being directly managed by her. 

From the above two businesses, Rasmita earns an average monthly income of 6,000 INR. According to her, this little income is insufficient to meet the day-to-day expenses of her family, as well as for procurement of paddy in bulk. So, to develop her livelihood status, she wants to earn some extra income by investing more in her existing business. Hence, she will utilize the present loan of 12,000 INR for procurement of paddy and to purchase lentils, oil, soap, potatoes, shampoo, salt, etc. for the general store. She expects a good return from this investment, as this is the right time for this business. 

Rasmita dreams to develop her general store into a big one and save some money for the better education of her child. 

Out of the other ten members, eight members are doing vegetable and paddy cultivation, and two members are running general grocery shops.

loans.use: to pay for procurement of paddy and purchase lentils, oil, soap, potatoes, shampoo, salt, etc.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana is a 48-year-old single mother with three daughters, two of whom are independent. She has been living in the same house for 25 years and a couple of years ago, she started selling shoes by catalog. Susana says that she also does domestic work and in her limited free time she enjoys listening to music. She is asking for a loan to buy more shoes. She says that now is the best retail season. In the future she would like to diversify into other products.

loans.use: To buy shoes for the end of year season

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goats and vaccines.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Rhodora sends you her gratitude for your generosity because her previous loan has enriched her business. She was able to buy additional supplies of meat products, which are needed to increase her inventory. The loan also helped her provide for her daily needs and expenses.

She is very positive that she could improve her business more if you will lend her 40,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional supplies of pork, chicken, and beef meat. Her customers will likely to buy more items if she has more of her products displayed at her store. An increase in sales will also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business to become viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family.

Aside from growing her business, Rhodora aims to have enough savings for her future goals. She meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies of pork, chicken, and beef meat needed in her business.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is thankful for the 10,000 PHP loan previously granted to her because she was able to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for their personal, household, and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jacqueline hopes that her business will continue to help support their daily needs. She meets up every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more ingredients needed in her food business. Her earnings were a big help for their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 17,000 PHP loan for her to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and expenditures. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Ludivina hopes to grow her business and dreams of gaining more regular customers. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of ingredients needed for making puto and other foods.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy’s business has been running very well since she received her loan in April 2014. The loan allowed her to grow the business and even to diversify to poultry, after realizing that the demand for clothes was getting low. With the proceeds from her business, she managed to make timely loan repayments, reinvest in the business, and retain funds to cover her financial needs.

Mercy plans to further diversify into a uniform-making business since there is a high demand in her community. Her desire is to get a second loan.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Deborah Group

texts.fr: La cliente MUHIGIRWA est âgée de 49 ans, présidente du groupe DEBORAH, mariée à un agent de l’Etat et mère de 7 enfants. Elle est vendeuse des produits divers de consommation à son domicile. Le prêt sollicité lui servira d’acheter 1 carton des piles, 50kgs de sucre, 2 cartons de bonbon, 2 carton de lait, 2 cartons de savon et 2 cartons de biscuit. Son rêve est d’ouvrir une grande boutique. Elle remercie HEKIMA  pour son soutien.
texts.en: This client named Muhigirwa is 49 years old and president of the Deborah group. She is married to a civil servant and has seven children. She sells various consumer products from her home. The loan that she requests will enable her to buy one box of batteries, 50 kg of sugar, two boxes of sweets, two cartons of milk, two boxes of soap, and two boxes of biscuits. Her dream is to open a big shop. She thanks Hekima for their support.

loans.use: to buy one box of batteries, 50 kg of sugar, two boxes of sweets, two boxes of milk, two boxes of soap, and two boxes of biscuits.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
SABOUGNOUMA est un groupe de l’association BENKOLA qui regroupe des femmes qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans. Mariées avec en moyenne  cinq enfants. Elles mènent différentes activités  telles la transformation des grains de néré en soumbala à l’image de DJENEBA qui est la troisième personne assise de la gauche vers la droite de la photo. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à OUELESSEBOUGOU, Préfecture de KATI (Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali). 
Elles sont dans le petit commerce depuis plusieurs années et sont très sollicitées dans leurs activités d’achat vente de grain de néré. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, il y a quatre ans. Elles sont à leur septième prêt solidaire. 
DJENEBA, qui est la présidente du groupe et très connue à COULOU, excelle dans la vente de soumbala. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 30 sacs de grains de néré pour la transformer en soumbala.  Elle s’approvisionne à OUELESSEBOUGOU auprès des grossistes  et vend ses produits à OUELESSEBOUGOU, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.   
Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et s’investir dans son activité d’achat vente de grain de néré.
texts.en:
Sabougnouma is a group of the Benkola association that regroups women who met through family and neighbourhood ties. On average they are 32 years old, and married with five children. They have different activities such as the transformation of locust beans into sumbala as is the case of Djeneba, who is the third person sitting from the left in the photo. They live in large traditional families in Ouelessebougou, in the Kati prefecture (Koulikoro region, Mali Republic)
They have worked in small businesses for several years and have a very good reputation in their locust bean commerce.
Hoping to satisfy the growing demand of their clientele, the members of this group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit programme four years ago. This is their seventh solidarity loan.
Djeneba, who is the president of the group and well-known in Coulou, excels in the sale of sumbala. She plans to use her loan to buy 30 sacks of locust beans for transformation into sumbala. She buys her supplies in Ouelessebougou, from the wholesalers and sells her products in Ouelessebougou , retail, for cash or for credit to a mixed clientele.
She hopes to make a monthly profit of 75.000FCFA that will enable her to repay the loan and reinvest in her locust bean business.

loans.use: to buy locust beans for transformation into sumbala.

loans.name: Annalisa

texts.en:
Annalisa sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan had expanded her business. She was able to purchase additional groceries that she needs in her store. The loan also helped her provide for the educational expenses of her child and pay for their daily needs.

She is very positive that she could further improve her business if you will let her borrow again, in the amount of PHP 60,000. This new loan will go to additional groceries, toiletries, and beverages. 

Her customers will likely buy more items, if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales should also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she could sustain the needs of her family.

Annalisa hopes that her business will continue to operate. She dreams of giving her family a good life. Every week, she meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages for her business.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie sends you her thanks for your generosity because her previous loan has entrenched her business. She was able to purchase additional merchandise, clothing and apparel needed to increase her product inventory. The loan also helped her provide for her daily needs.

She is very positive that she can improve her business more if you will lend her again an amount of 8,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional stocks of ready-to-wear items like shirts, pants, shorts and other clothing products. She will also purchase footwear products like shoes and sandals. Her customers are likely to buy more items if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales will also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she can sustain the needs of her family.

Rosemarie still wants to expand her store to house more products to sell. She also hopes that her family will always be free from sickness. She meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ready-to-wear products and merchandise items like shirts for men and women to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Muong Phang 12 Group

texts.en: Hoa, 51, has been a farmer since she was little so she has plenty of experience in traditional agricultural methods. For that reason, she works in agricultural production to provide for her family of six members, including her three sons, her husband and her daughter-in-law. They all also work at farming for a living with various activities such as planting vegetables and breeding pigs, chickens and fish. To better cover all of the living expenses for the big family, Hoa applied for a loan in the Anh Chi Em Program and she will use the loan to buy young fish and expand fish farming. She hopes that she could earn high income from this investment in order to gradually improve living conditions for her family. In the picture, Hoa is the Thai woman who wears the purple shirt and stands at the first from the right.

loans.use: to buy young fish and expand fish farming

loans.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca is the mother of five children, a mix of schooling and grown up. She was born in 1961 and is currently running a local restaurant known as mamalishe. She works hard everyday so as to capture more people. She starts working from 5 am to 8 pm per working day and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is her twelfth loan. She managed to repay successfully the previous loans. Rebeca invested much in her business, cooking new foods previously demanded and increased the size of food cooking, like from three to six kilos of rice and ugali. She is really proud of Kiva's support. She dreams that in the coming years she would like to build a nice house for her family. Rebeca received an extra income which she used to buy a few house items; TV, Digital, cupboard and bed and covered school fees and household expenses.

She will be held responsible for paying back this loan. With her credit request; she will invest in buying mamalishe food cooking ingredients.

loans.use: to buy mamalishe food cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Anny

texts.es: Anny,  es una emprendedora joven de 19 años de edad, que habita en el  municipio de Puerto Colombia y cuyo principal desafío es seguir estudiando para consolidar su negocio de productos ferreteros y artículos de navidad, que le fue heredado en el año 2012, por sus padres quienes antes se dedicaban a comercializar estos productos, pero ellos decidieron otorgárselo a su hija, haciendo reconocimiento a sus habilidades y destrezas en los negocios.  Anny aprovecha las temporadas de navidad para vender luces y adornos de esta época del año, mientras el resto del año vende herramientas y productos de ferretería su local.  Ella realiza sus compras a sus proveedores ferreteros de contado y está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, para   invertirlo en la compra de productos navideños, cintas, globos, arreglos, accesorios, adornos de navidad, teniendo en cuenta que estamos en vísperas de la navidad y que para tener éxito en su negocio de temporada es necesario hacer las compras pronto y tener un inventario renovado y a la vanguardia. Sus metas a largo plazo son comprar su apartamento, tener un local mas adecuado y con mejor surtido.
texts.en:
Anny is an enterprising 19 year old young woman.  She lives in the Puerto Colombia municipality.  Her main challenge is to continue her education in order to consolidate her business of selling hardware and Christmas items.  She inherited the business from her parents in 2012.  They used to sell these products, but they decided to give her the business.  They realized her abilities and skills in businesses.

Anny is taking advantage of the Christmas season to sell lights and decorations for this time of year.  During the rest of the year she sells tools and hardware items at her place.  She makes her purchases from the hardware providers for cash.

She is applying for a Kiva loan, her first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, in order to buy Christmas products, ribbons, balloons, arrangements, accessories, and Christmas decorations.  Keeping in mind that Christmas is almost here, and in order to be successful in her seasonal business, she needs to make her purchases soon.  She needs to have improved inventory that is on the cutting edge.

Her long term goals are to buy her apartment, to have a better place, and to have better stock.

loans.use: to buy Christmas products, ribbons, balloons, arrangements, accessories, and Christmas decorations.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal initially used the school tuck shop to sell groceries, but due to the shop's rental costs, she switched to selling from her home.

When Racheal  received an earlier loan, she ventured into poultry production and fuel. With a good market for these, she is now earning enough profit to look after her family and assist her in-laws financially when there is need. She is also able to help needy students by buying them stationary in the nearest school. In all three enterprises there is a market, and the businesses balance each other as they bring profit at different times.

In the near future, Racheal is hoping to see her enterprises grow, and plans to buy a small truck that will help her transport her items. To accomplish these goals, she looks forward to receiving a new loan to purchase sugar, salt and snacks in bulk.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, salt and snacks in bulk.

loans.name: Rugoye Group

texts.en:
Charles, who is in his early 30s, is married with one kid who is still in school. He has had a butcher business for four years now. He works from 4am to 7:30pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Charles's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use this loan to increase his beef to meet his customers' demand. He dreams of opening another butcher shop in a different area.

Charles will share this loan with his loan group "Rugoye" which consist of five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase his beef to meet his customers' demand.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda sends you her gratitude for your generosity because her previous loan has helped her business. She was able to purchase additional feed and other supplies which are needed to increase her product inventory. The loan was also helpful in the educational expenses of her children and their daily needs.

She is very positive that she can improve more her business if you will let her borrow again an amount of 15,000 PHP. This new loan will go to additional groceries, toiletries and beverages needed in her variety store business. Her customers will likely buy more items if she has more of her products displayed in her store. An increase in sales will also result in a significant increase in profit, which will also result in her business becoming viable and sustainable. Simultaneously, she can sustain the needs of her family.

Aside from becoming successful in business, Merlinda wants her family to have good health and a longer life. She meets every week with her *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: On Time Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma, who is in her mid 30s, is married, with three children who are still in school. She has been a food-vendor for 15 years now. She works from 5am to 11am daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be Mwajuma's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to restock the out-of-stock items in the food store. She dreams of taking her children to good schools.

Mwajuma will share this loan with her loan group, On Time Group, which consists of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock the out-of-stock items in the food store.

loans.name: Muong Phang 13 Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ut is 25 years old, married and has two children: a boy five years old and a girl two years old. Currently, they live with her husband's family in a small Thai traditional house in a remote village where people almost work at agricultural production for a living. Likewise, Ut's family mainly relies on farming to earn income, of which the most important production is cultivating rice. In addition, they diversify their production to mitigate the risk of occurring incidents and to have additional income by planting vegetables and breeding pigs, chickens, fish, and raising buffalo for ploughing. 

Mrs. Ut wants to expand their agricultural activities to gradually improve the living conditions for her family so she applied for a loan from the Anh Chi Em Program. This is the first loan she has received from the Program and she will use the loan to buy young fish and expand her fish farming business. Despite plenty of difficulties ahead, she is very determined to conduct her business plan because she wants to provide an abundant life for her children. 

In the picture, Mrs. Ut stands first from the right.

loans.use: to buy young fish and expand her fish farm

loans.name: Elezabeth

texts.en:
Elezabeth works hard to support her family. She is married and has a furniture making business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional wood, nails, paints, etc.

Elezabeth has been in this business for eight years now. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional wood, nails, paints, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase up-to-date decorating materials

loans.name: Emelita

texts.en:
Emelita is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a food-vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 8,000 through NWTF to purchase more stocks of frozen foods, meat, etc. to sell.

Emelita has been in this business for 3 years. She earns more income from farming vegetables.

Emelita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of frozen foods, meat, etc. to sell

loans.name: Felene Joy

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Felene Joy works hard to support her family.

She has a food-vending business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from farming rice. Felene Joy is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to  buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Felene Joy has been sustaining her business activities through her past loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Jhonna

texts.en:
Jhonna is 36 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school. Jhonna works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

Jhonna has been in this business for one year.

In the future Jhonna would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Nemia

texts.en:
Nemia is 52 years old and married with two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

Nemia has borrowed and paid back one loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Nemia aspires to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell like canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Muzainah

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Muzainah, a micro-entrepreneur from Jakarta, Indonesia. Jakarta has been known as the most populous city in Indonesia and in Southeast Asia. Muzainah is married, and she and her husband have been blessed with three children. Her husband works as an administrative staffer in a local company. Muzainah and her husband realized that living in such a large city would be challenging because of the higher living costs. Her husband’s pay has been supporting them well, but they are trying to find other ways to support their children’s education. 

Before Ruma, Muzainah was a stay-at-home housewife, taking care of her children. Three months ago, Muzainah met a Ruma agent, Ahmad, who introduced the mobile airtime business to her. Muzainah got excited to join Ruma, which empowers micro-entrepreneurs with technology to provide access to financial and informational services. 

As a new business, Muzainah has the advantage of selling to most of the women in her community – she is a friendly and sociable person. Most of her customers are her own female neighbors who have also adopted mobile phones.  As the business runs, Muzainah hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva that will be used to process more mobile phone airtime transactions. In the future, Muzainah plans to add more mobile services to her community, such as utility bill payment service. In the photo, Muzainah is pictured in her house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to have working capital to process mobile services in her community on the weekends

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a restaurant business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 10 years now.

She requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock of ingredients like meat, spices, eggs, canned goods, etc.

In the future, Perlita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of ingredients like meat, spices, eggs, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poplin, thread and stickers.

loans.name: Johanes

texts.en:
Johanes is 52 years old and married with one child who is in school. She works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Johanes has been in this business for 23 years. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Manilyn

texts.en:
Manilyn is 27 years old and married with one child. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a business buying and selling gasoline in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 8,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional gallons of gasoline to sell.

Manilyn has borrowed and paid one loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy-and-sell gasoline business for one year, and also earns income from farming vegetables and pig fattening. Manilyn aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional gallons of gasoline to sell.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Margie works hard to support her family. She has a food-vending business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from raising chickens. 

Margie is borrowing PHP 6,000 through NWTF to buy more stocks of food to sell like peanuts, corn, etc. for her food-vending business.

Margie hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of food to sell like peanuts, corn, etc

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is a hard-working entrepreneur who has a food-vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 7,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for food production for her food vending business.

Marissa has been in this business for 6 years. She earns more income from farming rice.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to build a house for her family in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is 57 years old, widowed, and has five children, one of whom is in school.

She is in the agricultural business of farming citrus in the Philippines. She has been farming citrus for 10 years now, and has borrowed 3 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Rosa requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and a new variety of citrus seeds. In the future, Rosa would like to save enough to buy more farmland.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and a new variety of citrus seeds

loans.name: Rosebella

texts.en:
Rosebella is 59 years old and married with three children. 

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like soap, shampoo, eggs, milk, etc.

Rosebella has borrowed and paid back 2 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from raising pigs.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like soap, shampoo, eggs, milk, etc.

loans.name: Shannel

texts.en:
Shannel is 28 years old, married, and works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming vegetables. Shannel is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Shannel has been sustaining her business activities through her past loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Zenia

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Zenia works hard to support her family.

She has a furniture making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rice and corn. Zenia is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to buy materials like wood, nails and paints, and to pay laborers' wages for her furniture making business.

Zenia has been sustaining her business activities through her past loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials like wood, nails and paints, and to pay laborers' wages.

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a buy-and-sell dried fish business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 18 years now.

She requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock of dried fish to sell. In the future, Merlita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia, a 52-year-old widowed mother of four, works hard to provide for her family. She has been running a direct-selling business for personal items in the Philippines for four years and also earns an income selling dried fish.

Leticia, who has borrowed and repaid eight previous loans from NWTF, has requested a new one for PHP 20000 loan to purchase additional stocks of personal collection items to sell. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks of personal collection items to sell

loans.name: Jitahidi Msakuzi Group

texts.en:
Beatrice, who is in her mid 40s, is married with two children who are still in school. She has been running a business of selling second-hand clothes for six months now. She works from 9:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Beatrice's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use it to buy different types of second-hand clothing. She dreams of having a new clothing shop.

Beatrice will share this loan with her loan group, "Jitahidi Msakuzi," which consists of four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy different types of second-hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
A married parent of seven children, Delia works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling rice in the Philippines and also earns income from farming rice.

Delia is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy more sacks of rice to sell through her "buy and sell" business.

Delia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to buy more farmlands.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily works hard to support her family. She is married and has a motorcycle repair shop business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 15 years now.

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional materials for her business. In the future, Emily would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her business.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita is 50 years old and married with one child. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 5,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

Juanita has been in this business for 25 years. In the future Juanita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Myren

texts.en:
Myren is 32 years old and married with two children who are in school. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, eggs, noodles, soap, shampoo, etc.

Myren has been in this business for 9 years. In the future she would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, eggs, noodles, soap, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Abigail S

texts.en: This is 34 year-old Abigail.  She is married and has two children ages five and two years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her because she is her relative and Abigail helps her with schooling.  In 2011, Abigail established her pharmacy business. She began her business to be self reliant after graduating from nursing school. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,100,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 5,000,000. Abigail requires a loan in order to buy more medicines for her pharmacy. In the future, Abigail plans to open a pharmacy in another town. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more medicines for her pharmacy.

loans.name: Ma. Flor

texts.en:
Ma. Flor is 56 years old, married and has four children. 

She is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Ma. Flor requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of feed for her pigs.

Ma. Flor has been raising pigs for 15 years, and has borrowed eight times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Ma. Flor would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of feed for her pigs

loans.name: Muhammad Arif

texts.en:
Hello, lenders! Meet Arif. Arif owns and manages a small shop that sells mobile phone airtime credits. Arif is happily married, and he and his wife have been blessed with one daughter. Together, this small family lives in Lebak, a rural area located on the west coast of Java.

To support his family’s needs, Arif decided to join Ruma three months ago. He is excited to do business as a Ruma agent, not only because he can raise his income by selling mobile phone airtime credits, but also because he can learn more about mobile technology use for businesses. By being a Ruma agent, Arif is able to give impact to his community. People had to go to some distance to find a mobile phone airtime kiosk and wait in line. But Arif is their neighbor and people can visit easily without wasting much time. 

Now, that the demand for mobile airtime is increasing (especially on the weekends), Arif is applying for the working capital loan from Kiva in order to process more airtime transactions. In the near future, Arif plans to add more products from Ruma to the things he sells, such as utility bill payment service and product catalogue service to his community.

loans.use: to access working capital to provide mobile services in his community on the weekends

loans.name: Ave

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ave works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing vending business in the Philippines, and also earns income from food vending.  Ave is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of fish for her fishing vending business to sell.

She successfully repaid her previous loan, and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Ave has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Abdulia

texts.en:
Abdulia is 57 years old and has one child. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 35,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items like soap, sardines, and other goods to sell .

Abdulia has been in this business for 10 years.

In the future, Abdulia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items like soap, sardines, and other goods to sell

loans.name: Candida

texts.en:
Candida is 54 years old and married with five children. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries and related goods to sell.

Candida has been in this business for nine years.

In the future, Candida would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo and groceries to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en: This is 44 year-old James.  He is married and has three children ages 5, 9 and 16 years old. He has one additional dependent who lives with him to help with the business.  In 2003, James established his electronics business. He began his business just to enable him to solve his domestic problems. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,200,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan of Le 5,000,000. James has already received and successfully repaid seven loans and now requires a new loan in order to buy mobile accessories and dozens of radios. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits, to diversify his product and get more income. In the future, James plans to rent a shop. start a wholesale trade and educate his children to the university level.  He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy mobile accessories and dozens of radio.

loans.name: Efred

texts.es: Efred, de 24 años de edad, logro identificar una oportunidad de negocio que había en el barrio donde reside en el municipio de Soledad.  Cuenta que por iniciativa propia, decidió tener una tienda de víveres, ya que en su barrio no había tiendas y en la actualidad esta es la única tienda, que existe y  funciona en el  horario  de 6 am a 7 pm diariamente.  A  Efred  le fue otorgado un crédito en Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual  aumentará su inventarios, para que sus vecinos puedan conseguir la gran mayoría de los productos de la canasta familiar. De esta forma se incrementaría la posibilidad de aumentar las ventas en su negocio y con ello mejorar el flujo de caja diario y generar la recompra de productos de consumo masivo.  Sus proveedores están ubicados en las afueras del municipio de soledad, a los cuales les compra de contado, y el gran desafío  de Efred es aumentar su capital porque el que tiene le es insuficiente. Él desea continuar brindándoles apoyo a sus familiares y tener un mejor stock de artículos para la venta.
texts.en:
Efred is 24 years old. He was able to find a business opportunity in the neighborhood where he resides, in the town of Soledad. 
He states, that on his own initiative, he decided to have a grocery store, because there were no stores in his neighborhood, and right now this is the only one. He opens from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m. every day.

Efred got a loan from Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo. He will use it to increase his inventory, so his neighbors can get most of the basic needs products.  He will be able to increase the business sales, and to improve the daily cash flow to buy basic consumer goods. 

His suppliers are located outside the town of Soledad. He buy from them paying cash. The big challenge for Efred is to increase his capital, because what he has now is not enough. 

He wishes to keep being able to support his family, and to have a better selection of articles for sale.

loans.use: to buy basic needs products, rice, oil, dairy products, meat products, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
Tita works hard to support her family. Tita is widow and has a buy and sell rice business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase sacks of rice to sell.

Tita has been in this business for three years now.

In the future, Tita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy wax cotton and “Bamako” materials. for her shop

loans.name: Mariama Seray

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Mariama.  She is married and has two children ages 15 and 6 years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her as an assistant in the business.  In 2008, Mariama established her plastic slippers business. She began her business to be self-reliant and to help her husband in the running of their home. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 700,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 4,000,000. Mariama requires a loan in order to buy more plastic slippers for her business. In the future, Mariama plans to extend the business to another town, educate her children well and to build a family dwelling house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more plastic slippers

loans.name: Mwendakasi Group

texts.en:
Suzana, who is in her midthirties, is single with 5 children. Two of the children are adults. She has been running a genge for one year. A genge is a shop about the size of a stall that sells basic food items for meal preparation.  She works from 8 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. daily. She is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Suzana's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to open a genge-duka (a small, neighborhood grocery store) and to increase stock in her store. She dreams of making a big genge-duka. 

Suzana will share this loan with her loan group, Mwendakasi, which consists of ten members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to open and stock a grocery store.

loans.name: Joemela

texts.en:
Joemela is 28 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items like shampoo, toothpaste, and groceries to sell.

Joemela has borrowed and repaid 28 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for eight years, and she also earns income from buying and selling rice and charcoal.

Joemela aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items like shampoo, toothpaste, and groceries to sell

loans.name: Dedis

texts.es: Dedis, fue  inspirada en su hermana quien le sugirió que  se incorporara al negocio de venta de productos de marroquinería, ropa, perfumes y cremas humectantes;  Dedis confió en esta propuesta, puesto que la experiencia y el conocimiento de su hermana le serian de gran utilidad. Este negocio inició en el año 2010, y ha sido su generador de ingresos, ella considera que el negocio podría mejorar si aumenta su inventario de productos,en la actuialidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer finaciamiento que le hace la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo,  para cumplir con su propósito comprando ropa, calzado, perfumes etc..  Ella es una mujer que a sus 36 años, piensa en su futuro y desea tener su propio apartamento y local comercial,  su desafío es vender mucho más y ahorrar para cumplir  sus proyectos. Este negocio es muy eficaz gracias a que ha logrado fidelizar a sus clientes por su buen servicio, productos atractivos y de calidad, además cuenta con una excelente rotación de cartera.
texts.en:
Dedis was inspired by her sister, who suggested to her that she join the business of selling leather goods, clothing, perfume, and moisturizing cream. Dedis believed her suggestion, since her sister's experience and knowledge would be very useful to her. She started this business in 2010 and it has been her source of income. She believes that she could improve her business if she were to increase her inventory of products. 

She is currently applying for a Kiva loan, her first with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, to accomplish her goal by buying clothing, footwear, perfume, etc. At the age of 36, she is thinking about her future and she would like to have her own apartment and a commercial property. Her challenge is to sell much more and save up for her projects. This business is very efficient thanks to the fact that she has managed to build loyalty among her clients due to her good service and attractive and high-quality products. She also has an excellent portfolio turnover.

loans.use: to buy clothing, footwear, perfume, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy perfumes and creams.

loans.name: Nelita

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Nelita works hard to support her family.

She has a business renting a house and rooms in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from buying and selling rice. Nelita is borrowing PHP 35,000 through NWTF to purchase materials for the maintenance for her rental house and rooms.

Nelita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials for the maintenance of her housing rental business
